An airstrike on Wednesday destroyed a hospital in the southeastern city, three people including one child. Ukraine's foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba described the situation in Mariupol as the most difficult in the country. 1,300 people are thought to have been killed there and efforts are now underway to collect and bury the dead.

sentences.sentence: Ukraine NATO is continuing to advocate for sanctions and diplomacy. While peace talks in Turkey failed to prompt any major changes, Ukraine's foreign minister said Kyiv remains ready for further discussions. But is President Putin ready to listen? Well, joining me now live is Matthew Breise, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council and also a former White House official.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much there for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: You're in Turkey.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Would you say that these talks that took place there in Turkey, were they doomed to fail from the start?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Per, thanks so much for having me and for asking that insightful question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Yes, they were doomed to fail from the start, because as Ukrainian Foreign Minister Kuleba said, Foreign Minister Lavrov appeared to be empowered to do nothing but to stick to the talking points of President Putin that are for extreme demands, that call for and ridiculously call for Ukraine to denazify and to demilitarize, and that Foreign Minister Lavrov refused to talk about what Kuleva came there to talk about, which was humanitarian assistance and humanitarian corridors. So the Russian side wanted to press its maximal political goals, and the Ukrainian side wanted to work on the humanitarian problem. And so they were, what they wanted, their goals were incompatible even to begin the talks. And what underlies all that is that President Putin, he's using military force as a tool of diplomacy. Military force is a tool of diplomacy. It's not a question of force or talking at the negotiating table. Putin is using military force to shape political reality to Russia's advantage. It's a brutal tactic, but it's part of diplomacy. And he's not finished yet, as your reporting has so poignantly pointed out. Russia is bombing civilians and the maternity hospital in Mariupol, and there's a huge humanitarian crisis happening there. And Russia is using that brutality as a diplomatic tool. So, no, these talks are not doomed to create a breakthrough, but maybe, maybe the start of a process, because eventually President Putin is going to have to find a way to negotiate an end to this war, because war is a continuation of politics by other means.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Matthew, I have to ask you, both the White House and we've also heard today from the UK Foreign Secretary voicing concern about Russia possibly preparing to use chemical weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: What's your analysis of that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yeah, it's terrifying.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And the Russian claims that the United States has been funding Ukrainian development of biological weapons or chemical weapons is absurd.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It's a canard.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: weapons or chemical weapons is absurd. It's a canard. The program that the United States has funded for years in Ukraine and Russia, by the way, and all the former Soviet Union, including Azerbaijan, where I was ambassador, is one to prevent biological or chemical weapons from being seized by nefarious groups like terrorists or as they decay from causing harm to the local environment. Russia knows what these programs are. Russia has been a willing participant until recently in such programs. So the fact that Russia would issue such bald-faced lies about such a program suggests definitely to me that they're looking for some sort of a false flag operation that would justify them using chemical or biological weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And by the way, it's still not justified, even if Ukraine had been developing biological or chemical weapons, which it wasn't, that still wouldn't justify Russia using such weapons on the battlefield.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: All right, Matthew Breiser, thank you so much for joining us here on Your News Tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting all 26 EU leaders in Versailles for a two-day summit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Exactly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Actually, the leaders raised two of the most important issues and urgent issues right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: On the other side, we have also Kiev's bid to join the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And there, we heard the French president, Emmanuel Macron, ruling out any discussion about this right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Because, as he said, the EU cannot open this kind of debate or discussion with a country where there is a real war on its territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And also we heard Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister, who, of course course we know that he is always very sceptical towards a further EU enlargement, that he said that there is no fast track process for EU membership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.sentence: Effie, thank you for that report live from Versailles and still to come here on your news tonight much more news do stay with us welcome back to the program Twitter has announced a privacy protected version of its site to bypass surveillance in Russia the social media platform was recently restricted in Russia as part of a crackdown on the flow of information about the war in Ukraine. Now here's Matthew in the Cube with more. Matthew. Well Per, since the very start Russian state media and the Kremlin have referred to this war in Ukraine as a quote special military operation. Since then Moscow has also cracked down further not just on news outlets but also social media platforms.

sentences.sentence: And in recent days, we've seen a number of people trying different ways to circumvent this Russian censorship and provide independent information about the war in Ukraine.

sentences.sentence: Well, now Twitter has announced a new privacy-protected version of its platform in an attempt to try and bypass Russian surveillance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was unveiled on Twitter's behalf by the internet security expert Alec Muffet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But what exactly does it mean, a privacy protected version of Twitter?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well it's what's referred to as an onion service, which Russian users can access if they download the Tor browser.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now this browser gives them access to materials on what is known as the dark web, where online users can remain anonymous, either for their own safety or where a website has been blocked by the Russian government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the main difference essentially is it's not Twitter.com, but it is now Twitter.onion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And the social media platform says it has been working on a project like this since before Russia launched its invasion in Ukraine two weeks ago pair we've seen various attempts by the West to try and circumvent this Russian censorship and provide independent information to Russian people about the war in Ukraine Twitter for their part now launching a privacy protected version to try and ensure that Russian users can get back on their site thank you thank you and we'll leave you with a note comment from the Kiev region, where refugees have been using humanitarian corridors to escape the capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
